title: Ex-Cop Who Killed Her Black Neighbor in His Own Home Found Guilty of Murder
text:
Amber Guyger. Photo: Tom Fox/AP

Amber Guyger, the Dallas police officer who shot and killed her black neighbor inside his own apartment last September, has been found guilty of murder.

On September 6, 2018, Guyger entered the apartment of her 26-year-old neighbor, Botham Jean, and fatally shot him. Prosecutors say he was watching TV and eating ice cream when Guyger came through his doorway and opened fire; she has maintained that she thought she was in her own apartment and was acting in self-defense. At the time of the shooting, per the New York Times, she was off-duty but in uniform.

Guyger — who was originally charged with manslaughter but later indicted for murder by a grand jury — spent her weeklong trial attempting to convince the courtroom that her response was reasonable. Prosecutors emphasized that Jean was “never a threat” to her and called forth witnesses who testified that the bullet trajectory indicated he was either rising from a sitting position or “in a cowering position” when he was shot, according to the Times. On Tuesday, after jurors deliberated for less than two days, Judge Tammy Kemp announced that the jury had found her guilty of murder.

The verdict makes this a rare case in which a white police officer was convicted of murder for using lethal force on an unarmed black person — in the 2014 murder of Eric Garner, for instance, the officer who wrestled the defenseless black man to the ground and choked him to death was never even indicted. Upon hearing the verdict on Tuesday, Jean’s family and the activists who have closely followed this case responded with relief.

“God is good — trust him,” Allison Jean, Botham’s mother, said as she left the courtroom. Alongside her, Botham’s grandmother walked out with her fist in the air.

Outside the courtroom, Lee Merritt, an attorney for the Jean family, celebrated the verdict as a “huge victory” — not just for the Jean family but for “all black people in America.”

“It’s a signal that the tide is going to change here,” Merritt told reporters. “Police officers are going to be held accountable for their actions, and we believe this is going to change the policing culture all over the world.”

Per NBC News, Guyger will be sentenced later today, around 1 p.m. Dallas time. She faces a sentence of between five and 99 years.

description: Follows Amber Guyger’s week-long murder trial, in which she tearfully testified that she never meant to kill Botham Jean, the Dallas cop was found guilty of murder.
